body:
<!-- Anything that looks like this is a comment and can't be seen after the Pull Request is created. -->

# PR Summary

Fix #17110
When the `PSCleanBlock` experimental feature is not enabled, `ProxyCommand.Create` should not generate the clean block for the proxy function.

After the fix,
1. **when the feature is disabled**, generated proxy function for `Get-Command` doesn't have the `clean` block in it:
    ```powershell
    PS:4> [System.Management.Automation.ProxyCommand]::Create($cm)
    [CmdletBinding(DefaultParameterSetName='CmdletSet', HelpUri='https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=2096579')]
    param(
       .... ## skip the long param block
       )
    
    begin
    {
        ... ## skip the long begin block
    }
    
    process
    {
        try {
            $steppablePipeline.Process($_)
        } catch {
            throw
        }
    }
    
    end
    {
        try {
            $steppablePipeline.End()
        } catch {
            throw
        }
    }
    
    <#
    
    .ForwardHelpTargetName Microsoft.PowerShell.Core\Get-Command
    .ForwardHelpCategory Cmdlet
    
    #>
    ```

2. **When the feature is enabled**, the generated proxy function for `Get-Command` has the `clean` block in it:
    ```powershell
    PS:3> [System.Management.Automation.ProxyCommand]::Create($cm)
    [CmdletBinding(DefaultParameterSetName='CmdletSet', HelpUri='https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=2096579')]
    param(
       ... ## skip the long param block
        )
    
    begin
    {
        ... ## skip the long begin block
    }
    
    process
    {
        try {
            $steppablePipeline.Process($_)
        } catch {
            throw
        }
    }
    
    end
    {
        try {
            $steppablePipeline.End()
        } catch {
            throw
        }
    }
    
    clean
    {
        if ($null -ne $steppablePipeline) {
            $steppablePipeline.Clean()
        }
    }
    
    <#
    
    .ForwardHelpTargetName Microsoft.PowerShell.Core\Get-Command
    .ForwardHelpCategory Cmdlet
    
    #>
    ```

## PR Checklist

- [x] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)
    - Use the present tense and imperative mood when describing your changes

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

As a user using the French keyboard layout, entering a forward slash (`Shift+:`) is _way more convenient_ than entering a backslash (`AltGr+8`). So using forward slashes throughout PowerShell has become muscle memory...

This works in most cases.

Alas, tab expansion for inputs like

````
\\hostname\x<TAB>
````

works, but this doesn't:

````
//hostname/x<TAB>
````


### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

1.  Create a WinRM remoting endpoint with 'RestrictedRemoteServer' session type.
Config.pssc file:
```powershell
@{
    SchemaVersion = '1.0.0.0'
    GUID = '324095c8-629a-489f-8c69-50595007c937'
    Author = 'contoso'
    CompanyName = 'Contoso'
    Copyright = '(c) Contoso. All rights reserved.'
    Description = 'Test Role'
    **SessionType = 'RestrictedRemoteServer'**
    TranscriptDirectory = 'E:\temp\Transcripts'
}
```
2.  Attempt to connect to the WinRM endpoint.

A parser error is returned to the client because the 'RestrictedRemoteServer' creates proxy commands, and the proxy commands include the new 'clean' block, even though the server session does not enable 'clean block' experimental feature.  Fix is to not include clean blocks in proxy commands if the experimental feature is not enabled.

Here is where the proxy commands are created:
https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/5e37308e1b4dbfff2eb89a21c38d401def40cb26/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/InitialSessionState.cs#L1430

### Expected behavior

```console
Successful connection to endpoint.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
A remoting error is returned:

New-PSSession: [localhost] Processing data from remote server localhost failed with the following error message: At line:63 char:1
+ clean
+ ~~~~~
unexpected token 'clean', expected 'begin', 'process', 'end', 'clean', or 'dynamicparam'. For more information, see the about_Remote_Troubleshooting Help topic.
```

_No response_

# Solution

* https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/17109#issuecomment-1089063661

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

I am providing PowerShell Core 7.2.2 on Fedora 35 Linux a PowerShell script that I have written locally. At the top of the file, I have a comment based help section with synopsis, description, and a link. However, when I use `Get-Help` nothing shows. The same happens when I use help except it opens a pager.

```powershell
<#
.NAME
    Export-ADOlibrary-RestAPI.ps1

.SYNOPSIS
    Export Azure DevOps Library Groups into JSON files.

.DESCRIPTION
    Export an Azure DevOps Library Group into a JSON file. Then use that file to
    set some parameters and save them as encrypted files in the Azure DevOps Git
    Repo.

.NOTE
    This script was written by person of company for project.
#>
# Print text
Write-Host "This is some output."
```

However, when I use the `Get-Help` and `help` commands, this is what I get

```powershell
> Get-Help ./Export-ADOlibrary-RestAPI.ps1
Export-ADOlibrary-RestAPI.ps1 

```

Same thing for `help ./Export-ADOlibrary-RestAPI.ps1`.

I should see the same thing as what's being described in the documentation for [Comment Based Help](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_comment_based_help?view=powershell-7.2#comment-based-help-for-a-function). 

### Expected behavior

```console
Display Comment Based Help
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Nothing displays
```

title: Bump Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.NetAnalyzers from 7.0.0-preview1.22202.1 to 7.0.0-preview1.22204.1

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Note: 
 * Conceptually related: #14534

The following two statements _should_ be equivalent, but aren't:

```powershell
# OK - with only a -Path argument, the path is taken *literally*
# Creates a subdir. literally named '[test]' with a file 'test.txt' in it.
New-Item -Force -Path '[test]\test.txt'

# !! BROKEN - with -Name also present, the -Path argument is
# !! interpreted as a *wildcard expression*
New-Item -Force -Path '[test]' -Name 'test.txt'
```

With `-Name` also present, `-Path` is unexpectedly treated _as a wildcard expression_.

### Expected behavior

Both commands should (re)create a subdirectory `[test]` with a file `test.txt` in it, and report a `FileInfo` instance for the latter; e.g.:

```console

    Directory: /Users/jdoe/[test]

UnixMode   User             Group                 LastWriteTime           Size Name
--------   ----             -----                 -------------           ---- ----
-rw-r--r-- jdoe             staff                4/4/2022 17:08              0 test.txt

```


### Actual behavior

The second command is situationally either a quiet no-op, or fails when wildcard pattern `[test]` matches an _existing file_ named `t` or `e` or ... or inappropriately targets an _existing directory_ named `t` or `e` ...

### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-preview.3
```


### Visuals

_No response_

### Steps to reproduce

When using `-PipelineVariable` upstream in a command to create and populate a variable, the value of that variable does not appear to be available when referencing it in `ForEach-Object -Parallel`

Instead, nothing seems to happen. The variable appears to be null.

To be sure, I tested it with both `$using:foo` and `$foo`, though I would assume `$using:foo` is the correct usage here.

### Expected behavior

```console
PS> 1..5 |
  ForEach-Object { $_ } -PipelineVariable foo |
  ForEach-Object -Parallel { $using:foo } -ThrottleLimit 2
1
2
3
4
5
PS>
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS> 1..5 |
  ForEach-Object { $_ } -PipelineVariable foo |
  ForEach-Object -Parallel { $using:foo } -ThrottleLimit 2
PS>
```

```console
N/A
```

# PR Summary

<!-- Summarize your PR between here and the checklist. -->

Some versions of .NET preview were released with version that don't have a number following the preview suffix, and your pattern won't match them correctly. It will include spaces and fail with FormatException when parsing. The pattern is unnecessarily strict about the format, and not properly escaped. Replacing the pattern with simpler one, and trimming whitespace. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5735905/161369928-56bb8fa5-7b58-4683-9e31-39883d56e455.png)

The existing pattern `\d*.\d*.\d*(-\w*\.\d*.\d*.\d*)?` does not escape the dots between numbers, and so the last `.` will match space.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5735905/161369908-9cfa4a03-b092-4457-8714-a2ffd84d249f.png)

## PR Context

<!-- Provide a little reasoning as to why this Pull Request helps and why you have opened it. -->

I have many .NET previews installed and don't want to remove them from my system to be able to build PS.

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Powershell is great, but there's a lot of very simple things that ideally shouldn't be quite as verbose as powershell requires. One of these is 'touch'

One thing for example is when I wanted to create the profile for my admin account, I would like to have been able to just do this:

```powershell
@'
$PSReadLineOptions = @{
    EditMode = "Emacs"
    HistoryNoDuplicates = $true
    HistorySearchCursorMovesToEnd = $true
                ShowToolTips = $true
}
Set-PSReadLineOption @PSReadLineOptions
'@ > $profile
```

But that's a no go, because several paths along the way to where $profile pointed didn't exist. So instead you have to go through this:

```powershell
mkdir -p $profile # Creates the entire path as a directory, including the very last item that should be just a file
rmdir $profile # Deletes the very last bit that should have been a file

@'
$PSReadLineOptions = @{
    EditMode = "Emacs"
    HistoryNoDuplicates = $true
    HistorySearchCursorMovesToEnd = $true
                ShowToolTips = $true
}
Set-PSReadLineOption @PSReadLineOptions
'@ > $profile
```

Would be nice if I could just do 'touch $profile' and be done with it, or if > would create the path and file if needed. Or even better: Both. Yes, I know you can just create an alias for it, but aliases don't really help all that much in a lot of cases, particularly in this situation. In cases like this where you're setting up an account you haven't used before, or even logging into a system you haven't used that particular account on before.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

title: Skip failing scriptblock tests

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Daily CI builds are failing on Linux platforms because two script block logging tests are failing.  One reason for the failures I found on my local Ubuntu 18.04 Linux VM, is because the complex regex matching failed in some cases.  I fixed this by creating simpler matching, but the tests continued to fail in CI builds.  The failure in CI builds appears to be because the tests picked up the wrong log entries, as the log text did not look like a script block log.

### Expected behavior

```console
CI script block logging tests to pass on Linux platforms
```


### Actual behavior

```console
CI script block logging tests failing due to regex match failure, and incorrect log entries.
```

_No response_

title: Scriptblock logging tests failing in CI for Linux platforms

body:
<!-- Anything that looks like this is a comment and can't be seen after the Pull Request is created. -->

# PR Summary

Fixes failing logging tests on Linux platform.

## PR Context

This change removes regex matching on log contents, and replaces with less strict matching for just specific elements expected to be shown for script block logging.

The intent is to make these tests less fragile while still verifying that script block logging occurs with needed information, while also making the tests more readable and maintainable.

## PR Checklist

title: Bump Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.NetAnalyzers from 7.0.0-preview1.22116.1 to 7.0.0-preview1.22180.6

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.

### Steps to reproduce

run the following script you will see the cookies added are of size 20

```
$session = New-Object Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.WebRequestSession

$count = 0
1..100 | ForEach-Object { 
  $cookie = New-Object System.Net.Cookie
  try {
```

### Steps to reproduce

This is a weird one. 
I have a pwsh script that calls `psql` which in turn runs a `.sql` script which runs fine if I invoke the script from shell, but it would stuck if run from a program with `pwsh -file script.ps1`.
(The program is running as root)

I found that the issue is only with Linux binaries or native shell commands.
For example, a simple script like this would be stuck.
```pwsh
ls
```
or 

```pwsh
ls > /tmp/test.out
Set-Content /tmp/continue "good"
```
However, as long as I only use pwsh commands, the script would finish.

Also, the linux binaries like `psql` and `ls` does actually run to finish but stuck at passing back control to the pwsh script.
In the above test script, `/tmp/test.out` does actually get written but the `Set-Content` never gets run.

```console
The script continues running
```

### Steps to reproduce

Putting breakpoint on return will stop on next line rather on return itself. 

```powershell
function TestMe {
    [cmdletBinding()]
    param(

    )

    $Test = Get-Verb

    Write-Host "Test"
    return
}

function TestMe2 {
    [cmdletBinding()]
    param(

    )

    $Test = Get-Verb


    if ($test.count -eq 5) {
        Write-Host "test1"
        return
    } elseif ($test.count -eq 1) {
        Write-Host "test"
        return
    }
    Write-Host "Test"
    return
}

TestMe2
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15063294/160710849-527ec8a3-330b-4383-b18a-8334fd79b767.png)

Originally reported in https://github.com/PowerShell/vscode-powershell/issues/3896

According to @SeeminglyScience it's a PowerShell bug:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15063294/160710991-f8b83f6b-2365-4405-a72f-46ee7afccd17.png)

This gets even worse if you try to do a blank line after return and put a breakpoint on return. 

```powershell
function TestMe2 {
    [cmdletBinding()]
    param(

    )

    $Test = Get-Verb


    if ($test.count -eq 5) {
        Write-Host "test1"
        return
    } elseif ($test.count -eq 1) {
        Write-Host "test"
        return
    }
    Write-Host "Test"
    return

}

TestMe2
```

Breakpoint won't be hit. If you put `return ""` breakpoint will work properly. 


### Expected behavior

```console
Breakpoint should be at return as expected.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Breakpoint stops 1 line after expected place
```

# PR Summary

Tab completions for a blank between a comma and something (e.g. parameter) does not work.

For example, the No. 1 in the following cases works well, but the No. 2 does not:

No. | o/x | Command and \<tab\>                   | `lastAst`     | `lastAst is`
--: | :-: | :------------------------------------ | :------------ | :----------------
  1 | ⭕ | `Get-Command -Type Alias,<tab>`       | {Alias,}      | [ErrorExpressionAst]
  2 | ❌ | `Get-Command -Type Alias,<tab> -All`  | {Alias, -All} | [ArrayLiteralAst]

That is because the tab completion is triggered if the `lastAst` is `ErrorExpressionAst`. Not triggered if `ArrayLiteralAst`. There are same issues other than the `Get-Command`, for example, `dir` (`Get-ChildItem`), `Get-Alias`, `Get-Module`, etc.

I have fixed the condition of triggering the tab completion. It is triggered if the `lastAst` is `ErrorExpressionAst` or `ArrayLiteralAst`.

## PR Context

It helps us to modify such an array, especially when we use Alt+a key (SelectCommandArguments).

## PR Checklist

- [x] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)
    - Use the present tense and imperative mood when describing your changes

    - [x] [Make sure you've added a new test if existing tests do not effectively test the code changed](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#before-submitting)
- **Tooling**

title: Class with hidden property breaking for-display formatting?

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

[about_Trap](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_Trap) states that trap statements may be defined anywhere within a given scope, but always apply to all statements in that scope. When using input processing methods (begin, process, end), variables act as though there is a consistent scope however the trap statement does not. Below is an extended example of this action.

```
begin {
    Write-Output "Block is: begin"
    "Scope is: " + (Get-Variable -Name Scope -Scope Private -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue).Value
    "Set Scope to : " + (Set-Variable -Name Scope -Scope Private -Value "begin" -Option Private -PassThru).Value

    trap {
        Write-Output "Block is: trap"
        "Scope is: " + (Get-Variable -Name Scope -Scope Private -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue).Value
        "Set Scope to : " + (Set-Variable -Name Scope -Scope Private -Value "trap" -Option Private -PassThru).Value
        continue
    }
}

process {
    Write-Output "Block is: process"
    "Scope is: " + (Get-Variable -Name Scope -Scope Private -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue).Value
    "Set Scope to : " + (Set-Variable -Name Scope -Scope Private -Value "process" -Option Private -PassThru).Value

    throw "error"
}

end {
    Write-Output "Block is: end"
    "Scope is: " + (Get-Variable -Name Scope -Scope Private -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue).Value
    "Set Scope to : " + (Set-Variable -Name Scope -Scope Private -Value "end" -Option Private -PassThru).Value
}

```

Using the trap statement outside of the input processing methods (begin, process, end) causes unexpected token and/or not recognized term errors. A workaround seems to be to use the source or dot operator on the input processing method blocks to bring them into the same scope. I am not sure if this was intended as using this method does not allow continued execution.

```
trap {
    Write-Output "Block is: trap"
    "Scope is: " + (Get-Variable -Name Scope -Scope Private -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue).Value
    "Set Scope to : " + (Set-Variable -Name Scope -Scope Private -Value "trap" -Option Private -PassThru).Value
    continue
}

. {
    begin {
        Write-Output "Block is: begin"
        "Scope is: " + (Get-Variable -Name Scope -Scope Private -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue).Value
        "Set Scope to : " + (Set-Variable -Name Scope -Scope Private -Value "begin" -Option Private -PassThru).Value


    }

    process {
        Write-Output "Block is: process"
        "Scope is: " + (Get-Variable -Name Scope -Scope Private -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue).Value
        "Set Scope to : " + (Set-Variable -Name Scope -Scope Private -Value "process" -Option Private -PassThru).Value

        #throw "error"
    }

    end {
        Write-Output "Block is: end"
        "Scope is: " + (Get-Variable -Name Scope -Scope Private -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue).Value
        "Set Scope to : " + (Set-Variable -Name Scope -Scope Private -Value "end" -Option Private -PassThru).Value
    }
}
```

If it is intended that the trap statement is bound by script blocks, that should be documented as it not currently intuitive.

### Expected behavior

```console
Block is: begin
Scope is:
Set Scope to : begin
Block is: process
Scope is: begin
Set Scope to : process
Block is: trap
Scope is:
Set Scope to : trap
Block is: end
Scope is: process
Set Scope to : end
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Block is: begin
Scope is:
Set Scope to : begin
Block is: process
Scope is: begin
Set Scope to : process
Exception: \test-trap.ps1:21
Line |
  21 |      throw "error"
     |      ~~~~~~~~~~~~~
     | error
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.2
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.2
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22000
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

_No response_

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

The `-Property` parameter (conveniently) interprets its arguments as _wildcard expressions_, so that `'foo' | Select-Object Len*` select the `.Length` property, for instance.

While perhaps a rare scenario, user may want to select properties that _literally_ contain a `*` character (see [this Stack Overflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/q/71618454/45375) for an example).

While escaping the `*` as `` `* `` is effective in bypassing the wildcard matching,  _the `` ` `` char. is inappropriately retained as part of the resulting property name_.

Note:

* If there's a performance concern with respect to correcting this behavior, the pitfall should at least be _documented_.

* The workaround is to use a _calculated property_ (see linked Stack Overflow post).

```powershell
'foo' | Select Len*, 'Bar`*'
```


### Expected behavior

```console
Length Bar*
------ -----
     3
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Length Bar`*
------ -----
     3 
```

That is, the `` ` `` was unexpectedly retained as part of the property name.


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

Update-Help: Failed to update Help for the module(s) 'ConfigDefenderPerformance, PSReadline' with UI culture(s) {en-US} : One or more errors occurred. (Response status code does not indicate success: 404 (The specified blob does not exist.).).
English-US help content is available and can be installed using: Update-Help -UICulture en-US.

```console
The update-help should not be showing these errors;
```

### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Microsoft Windows operating system comes with preinstalled virtual printers such as _Microsoft Print to PDF_, _Microsoft XPS Document Writer_, _Fax_, etc.

Sometimes it is required to select only the hardware printers (Cannon, HP, etc.).

The ```Get-Printer``` cmdlet does not have an object that differentiates between hardware and software printers. 

I'm suggesting to introduce a new object to specify the type of printer.

Would be great if $PSVersionTable could include some more relevant information to its' environment. For instance:

## OS agnostic

* [New key] .NET version built upon
* [New key] OS Architecture (x64, x86, ARM, ARM64 etc.)
* [New key] Process architecture (x64, x86, ARM, ARM64 etc.)

## Windows

* [Existing key] Update "OS" key to include build number (cumulative)
* [Existing key] Update "OS" key to include edition (Home / Pro / Enterprise)
  * If someone can't get BitLocker cmdlets to work, but running Windows 10 Home.. :)

<hr>

I'm thinking suggested additions in addition to being useful for end users, might be helpful when adding ```$PSVersionTable``` to issues on GitHub too, to give some more context out of the box.

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

TL;DR: I want to prompt user for input from a runspace, which I'm using to isolate a running script.

**Context:**
As part of a larger project, I'm executing PowerShell scripts, which may be distributed between machines with different PowerShell configurations. To make the environment more consistent, I'm running the scripts using `Start-Job ... | Receive-Job -Wait`, and inside the job, I set `$PSModuleAutoLoadingPreference` to `"None"` and explicitly import a few built-in modules. That way, the scripts behave the same even if user overrides a cmdlet with a different implementation, registers a conflicting alias or forgets about a hidden dependency on an installed module.

However, for this usecase, PowerShell jobs has a needlessly large overhead of creating a full new PowerShell instance, which takes a few hundred milliseconds on my machine. This is why I started looking into using runspaces instead, which have better startup and can share live objects with the main runspace.

---

**Issue:**
However, some of the scripts require interactive input from the user using `Read-Host` and `$Host.UI.PromptForChoice(...)`. When a job is used and received with `Receive-Job -Wait`, these interactive cmdlets work correctly and user can respond. However, when running under a runspace, the Host is not interactive and the following error is thrown:
```
A command that prompts the user failed because the host program or the command type does not support user interaction. Try a host program that supports user interaction, such as the PowerShell Console, and remove prompt-related commands from command types that do not support user interaction.
```

From my understanding, it should be easier to implement interactivity for runspaces than it was for jobs, given that runspaces run in the same process. At the same time, this would bring `ForEach-Object -Parallel`, which uses runspaces internally, a bit closer to ordinary script blocks in terms of features.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Currently, I figured out this terrible workaround, which works, but it's brittle and hacky:

```powershell
# % -Parallel is used because it internally handles many ugly details of working with runspaces,
#  no actual parallelism is done :)
% -Parallel {
    sleep 1 # some work
    # send a prompt request – a tuple containing our runspace, and a prompt message
    ,@([runspace]::DefaultRunspace, "Tell me something")
    # we now need to block and wait until the user enters something; a wait on a custom event seems the easiest for this demo
    $response = (Wait-Event -SourceIdentifier "HostInput").MessageData
    # we got a response, print it out
    echo "Response: $response"
    sleep 1 # more work
} | % {
    if (@($_).Count -ne 2 -or $_[0] -isnot [runspace]) {
        return $_ # not a prompt request, forward the data to the output
    }
    $rs, $prompt = $_
    $response = Read-Host -Prompt $prompt
    # trigger an event, which wakes up the runspace, and send the response
    $null = $rs.Events.GenerateEvent("HostInput", $null, $null, $response)
}
```

If you do not wish to implement full interactivity for runspaces, I'm open to less hacky solutions in a similar spirit. :)

# PR Summary

During refactoring of nuget.yml for SBOM changes, creating checksum for global tool packages was missed. This change adds back creation of a checksum file for global tool packages.

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Context

After investigating PowerShell Session Configuration for MicrosoftDocs/PowerShell-Docs#8583 (relevant notes below for reference) and talking to @PaulHigin, my understanding is that:

1. The functionality covered by these parameters is not _intended_ to work in PowerShell.
1. The existing behavior of these parameters is unexpected as a user and undocumented.
1. The **PowerShellVersion** parameter should be removed from `New-PSSessionConfigurationFile`.
1. The **PSVersion** parameter should be removed from `Register-PSSessionConfiguration` and `Set-PSSessionConfiguration`.
1. `Test-PSSessionConfigurationFile` should, if the **PowerShellVersion** key is set, inform the user (error, warn, or something else) that the key cannot be used for PowerShell session configurations.

### Steps to reproduce

In PowerShell 7+, the **PSSessionConfiguration** cmdlets (enumerated below) still include a parameter for specifying the version of PowerShell associated with a session configuration.

| Cmdlet | Parameter |
| ------ | --------- |
| `New-PSSessionConfigurationFile` | **PowerShellVersion** |
| `Register-PSSessionConfiguration` | **PSVersion** |
| `Set-PSSessionConfiguration` | **PSVersion** |

To confirm this:

```powershell
$null -eq ((Get-Command -Name New-PSSessionConfigurationFile).Parameters.Keys -match 'PowerShellVersion')
$null -eq ((Get-Command -Name Register-PSSessionConfiguration).Parameters.Keys -match 'PSVersion')
$null -eq ((Get-Command -Name Set-PSSessionConfiguration).Parameters.Keys -match 'PSVersion')
```

### Expected behavior

```console
$true
$true
$true
```


### Actual behavior

```console
$false
$false
$false
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.3.0-preview.2
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.3.0-preview.2
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19044
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

_No response_

### Investigation Notes

1. Valid versions for session config are reported as 2.0 -> 5.1
   - When using the value in a PSSC:

     ```text
     Register-PSSessionConfiguration: The value 7.2 is not valid for the PSVersion parameter.
     The available values are 2.0, 3.0, 4.0, 5.0, 5.1.
     ```

   - When overriding with the `-PSVersion` flag of `Register-PSSessionConfiguration`:

     ```text
     Register-PSSessionConfiguration:
        Cannot bind parameter 'PSVersion' to the target. Exception setting "PSVersion": "The value 7.2 is not valid for the PSVersion parameter.
        The available values are 2.0, 3.0, 4.0, 5.0, 5.1."
     ```

   - Default Session Configurations with 7.2.2 (after calling `Enable-PSRemoting`):

     ```text
     Name          : PowerShell.7
     PSVersion     : 7.2
     StartupScript :
     RunAsUser     :
     Permission    : NT AUTHORITY\INTERACTIVE AccessAllowed, ...
 
     Name          : PowerShell.7.2.2
     PSVersion     : 7.2
     StartupScript :
     RunAsUser     :
     Permission    : NT AUTHORITY\INTERACTIVE AccessAllowed, ...
     ```

1. `Test-PSSessionConfigurationFile` does not catch this.
1. There is no apparent way to _choose_ a new session configuration for 7x _but_ new session configurations created in 7x are automatically created with their PSVersion and `Enable-PSRemoting` in 7x will register a session configuration for that version (ie `PowerShell.7.2.2`) _and_ set (or register if it does not exist).
1. Repro:

   ```powershell
   New-PSSessionConfigurationFile -Path ./test.pssc -MountUser
   Register-PSSessionConfiguration -Path ./test.pssc -Name mount_test_7x
   Get-PSSessionConfiguration -Name mount_test* | Format-List -Property Name, PSVersion
   ```

   ```text
   Name      : mount_test_7x
   PSVersion : 7.2
   ```

   Open a Windows PowerShell prompt and:

   ```powershell
   Register-PSSessionConfiguration -Path ./test.pssc -Name mount_test_5x
   Get-PSSessionConfiguration -Name mount_test | Format-List -Property Name, PSVersion
   ```

   ```text
   Name      : mount_test_7x
   PSVersion : 7.2

   Name      : mount_test_5x
   PSVersion : 5.1
   ```

```cpp
#include <iostream>

using namespace std;

int main(int argc, char *argv[]) {
    for(int i = 1; i < argc; i++ )
        cout << "  argv[" << i << "]   "
        << argv[i] << "\n";

    return 0;
}
```

### Expected behavior

```console
argv[1] -some=some.key
argv[2] -skey=a.main

```


### Actual behavior

```console
argv[1] -some=some
argv[2] .key
argv[3] -skey=a
```

body:
### can not use full-width single quotes on title?

```
＠＂string＂＠
```

# Context:
Powershell often interacts with other command line and terminal software. cmd, bash, etc. 
These software use single quotes, double quotes. So, in powershell, you can't use single quotes, or double quotes, unless you use escaping.
At present, powershell supports the use of full-width single quotes and full-width double quotes, which partially solves the escaping problem, but it is not enough.

Why？
Because on the powershell command line, full-width single quotes will form a pair with single quotes,
which violates the powershell rule **not to use any single and double quotes**.

**This Enhancement mainly solves the problem of command line escaping and compatibility with other shells.
It's like cybersquatting a domain name.
pwsh sucks if other shells use this idea first.**

### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

I was expecting [within script] and command line parse to support here-strings like this:
```powershell
ssh root@ip " pwsh -c ＠“   1+2 ; write-host “abc” ”＠ "
```
Especially the command line.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

# Rules: (discussion welcome)
1 break change,let pwsh recognize the outermost here-string as the start and end of a powershell command.
Only full-width single quotation marks and full-width double quotation marks can be used inside, and there cannot be any single quotation marks or double quotation marks.


```
pwsh -c  ＠＂powershell code＂＠
```

or


```
pwsh -c ＠＇powershell code＇＠
```

or

```
pwsh -c2   ＠＂【single quotes】  new line 」   〖 double quotes〗＂＠             ? 
```



2let pwsh recognize the inner here-string as here-string.

----

# tips
ps > ssh root@ip { pwsh -c '1+1' } # not work，you cannot replace double quotes with "{" on powershell or pwsh

# Here-strings
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_quoting_rules?view=powershell-7.2

----

My plan b, I don't like it,You don't like it either.

```
cdip 1.2.3.4; $a = krun { powershell command on node }
or
$a = k_run_ip -ip 1.2.3.4 { powershell command on node }
```
It encapsulates the powershell remote, at least you can use {} instead of single quotes, double quotes.

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

On Windows, when you combine `Start-Process -Wait` with `-Credential` (running as a different user), the process is launched, BUT
* an `Access denied` error is reported
* no waiting occurs.

By contrast, using `-PassThru` and `.WaitForExit()` on the passed through `System.Diagnostics.Process` instance works fine.

```powershell
# Run on Windows
# Be sure to specify valid credentials when prompted.
Start-Process -Credential (Get-Credential) cmd  -Wait
```

### Expected behavior

No error should occur, and the call should block until the launched `cmd` instance is exited.


### Actual behavior

The `cmd` instance is launched, but, instead of waiting, an `Access denied` error is emitted.

Contrast this with this seemingly equivalent command, which works as expected:

```powershell
(Start-Process -Credential (Get-Credential) cmd -PassThru).WaitForExit()
```

### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-preview.2 on Windows
```


### Visuals

_No response_

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce




In the XML docs for `Cmdlet.WriteDebug`, it says that it throws `System.InvalidOperationException` if you call `WriteDebug` outside of ProcessRecord/Begin/EndProcessing:

https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/10027be363cf37c5888befb7126b6f4a5380e314/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/cmdlet.cs#L611-L616

however, in the code right below it, it actually throws a `System.NotImplementedException`

https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/10027be363cf37c5888befb7126b6f4a5380e314/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/cmdlet.cs#L633-L642

and indeed, if you make a sample cmdlet and have a constructor for the cmdlet, and call `this.WriteDebug("debug!");` in it, it throws `NotImplementedException`.

So I feel like the XML docs are wrong here, however the exception `InvalidOperationException` makes more sense, since `Cmdlet.WriteDebug` (and friends)` are implemented, you just called it at the wrong spot in the processing.

the powershell window:

```plaintext

PS C:\Users\mgrandi\source\repos\TestCmdlet\bin\Debug\netstandard2.0> Test-writedebugcmdlet
Test-writedebugcmdlet: WriteDebug


PS C:\Users\mgrandi\source\repos\TestCmdlet\bin\Debug\netstandard2.0> $error[0].Exception.StackTrace
   at System.Management.Automation.Cmdlet.WriteDebug(String text)
   at TestCmdlet.TestWriteDebugCmdlet..ctor() in C:\Users\mgrandi\source\repos\TestCmdlet\TestWriteDebugCmdlet.cs:line 16
   at lambda_method17(Closure )
   at System.Management.Automation.CommandProcessor.ConstructInstance(Type type)
   at System.Management.Automation.CommandProcessor.Init(CmdletInfo cmdletInformation)
PS C:\Users\mgrandi\source\repos\TestCmdlet\bin\Debug\netstandard2.0>


```

error from visual studio:

```plaintext

System.NotImplementedException
  HResult=0x80004001
  Message=WriteDebug
  Source=System.Management.Automation
  StackTrace:
   at System.Management.Automation.Cmdlet.WriteDebug(String text)
   at TestCmdlet.TestWriteDebugCmdlet..ctor() in C:\Users\mgrandi\source\repos\TestCmdlet\TestWriteDebugCmdlet.cs:line 16
   at System.Management.Automation.CommandProcessor.ConstructInstance(Type type)
   at System.Management.Automation.CommandProcessor.Init(CmdletInfo cmdletInformation)



```


source code of my test cmdlet that I used: 

```csharp
using System;
using System.Collections.Generic;
using System.Text;
using System.Management.Automation;
using System.Management.Automation.Runspaces;

namespace TestCmdlet
{
    [Cmdlet(VerbsDiagnostic.Test, "WriteDebugCmdlet")]
    [OutputType(typeof(FavoriteStuff))]
    public class TestWriteDebugCmdlet : PSCmdlet
    {

        public TestWriteDebugCmdlet()
        {
            this.WriteDebug("this is debug!");
        }

        [Parameter(
            Mandatory = false,
            Position = 0,
            ValueFromPipeline = true,
            ValueFromPipelineByPropertyName = false)]
        public int ValueOne { get; set; }

       

        // This method gets called once for each cmdlet in the pipeline when the pipeline starts executing
        protected override void BeginProcessing()
        {
            WriteVerbose("Begin!");
        }

        // This method will be called for each input received from the pipeline to this cmdlet; if no input is received, this method is not called
        protected override void ProcessRecord()
        {

            WriteObject(String.Format("ValueOne (int): `{0}`", ValueOne));

        }

        // This method will be called once at the end of pipeline execution; if no input is received, this method is not called
        protected override void EndProcessing()
        {
            WriteVerbose("End!");
        }

    }

}



```



### Expected behavior

```console
N/A, xmldocs bug
```


### Actual behavior

```console
N/A, xmldocs bug
```


### Error details

```console
N/A, XMLdocs bug
```

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
```

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Apologies if my search-foo isn't working, but I can find this 

When run in Windows Terminal or in VSCode - but not in the legacy host child windows open behind the active window. 
So if one runs (e.g.) Notepad it's **not** a child window and it appears in the foreground, but `Get-Help -showWindow` or `Out-GridView` are often hidden (this is most obvious when running on a single screen - sometimes they will open on the other screen so *are* visible)

### Expected behavior

```console
Child Window is visible
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Child Window is hidden behind VS-Code or Windows Terminal
```


### Error details

```console
No message
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value[0m
----                           -----[0m
PSVersion                      7.2.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19042
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0ΓÇª}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16209593/158981153-dfd3a475-2eab-44d3-82cc-6160f024e345.png)

This show what happens immediately after running the command, an icon appears on the task bar for the child window, but VSCode (in this case) remains in the foreground giving the impression that nothing has happened. If code is running full screen you don't see the icon appear so nothing seems to have happened  but clicking the icon gives access. In dual screen mode the window may appear on another screen

### Steps to reproduce

I experienced this issue when I went to leverage Chef InSpec to run https://github.com/vmware/dod-compliance-and-automation (a compliance check against VMware DISA STIG's).

1. Using RHEL 8.4 or Ubuntu 18.04 (tested against both OS's)
2. Install PowerShell Core 7.2.1
3. Install Chef InSpec ver. 4.52.9
4. Git Clone https://github.com/vmware/dod-compliance-and-automation
5. Run the Chef InSpec role to run a complaince check against a ESXi https://github.com/vmware/dod-compliance-and-automation/blob/master/vsphere/7.0/vsphere/inspec/vmware-vsphere-esxi-7.0-stig-baseline/README.md


### Expected behavior

```console
When run on PowerShell Core 7.2.0 this works without issue.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Only thing i am not sure of is which tool is at fault, hence why i have issue open at InSpec Train https://github.com/inspec/train/issues/725
```

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Here is the dotnet issue: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/66746
Here is the breaking change note: https://github.com/dotnet/docs/issues/28720

Basically, `System.Net.NetworkInformation.Ping` doesn't support specifying payload on Linux:
- it throws `PlatformNotSupported` exception when custom Ping payload is specified, when the process is not running as root.
- even if running as root (sudo), the custom payload is simply ignored because on Linux it's implemented by interfacing with the `ping` native utility, which doesn't support specifying custom payload.

So, whatever functionality in `Test-Connection` that depends on specifying custom payload is broken and should be either fixed or removed.

**Attention**: Workaround was added to test code in `Test-Connection.Tests.ps1` by https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/16930. Please fix the tests when resolving this bug, or removing the related tests if the affected functionalities will be removed.

```console
N/A
```

### Steps to reproduce

On Windows, run the following script in PowerShell 7.2.1:

```powershell
Install-Module -Name IISAdministration
Import-Module IISAdministration
Get-Module -ListAvailable
```

I have confirmed on a VM running 19042 that the Windows 10 build is not a factor as far as I can tell, because on a 20H2 VM I still see the problem behavior. I have also enabled IIS Management Console and IIS Management Scripts and Tools. The bulk of the documentation I could find referred to earlier versions of PowerShell 7 not supporting IISAdministration, but this doesn't seem to apply to 7.2.1 - if it did globally, I wouldn't have myself and multiple other team members running the scripts with no issues. I appreciate any help!

I did see in issue #13818 the reporter was told to look in the https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShellModuleCoverage repo and I reported the issue there as well, but then I saw the repo appears to be defunct. Its last commit was literally 4 years ago. ALl the other issues I can find reported for IISAdministration and PowerShell Core / 7 are at least two years old and refer specifically to earlier versions of PowerShell being incompatible, but I can see from the fact that the module works on several developer machines in my department that is no longer true.

### Expected behavior

The import should succeed and the module should be listed:

```console
Script     1.1.0.0               IISAdministration                   Core,Desk {Get-IISServerManager, Set-IISConfigAtt…
```

### Actual behavior

The import fails with the following error:

```console
Import-Module: Could not load file or assembly 'Microsoft.Web.Administration, Version=7.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=31bf3856ad364e35'.

The system cannot find the file specified.
```

The Get-Module list shows no cmdlets associated with IISAdministration:

```none
Script     1.1.0.0               IISAdministration                   Core,Desk
```

_No response_

# PR Summary

This PR implements the Custom Remote Connections RFC:
https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-RFC/blob/master/Archive/Draft/RFC0063-Custom-Remote-Connections.md

## PR Context

These changes open up the internal PowerShell remoting API so that custom connections can be created as PowerShell modules. This PR does not introduce any new functions, and instead selectively makes some previously internal APIs public so that third parties can create custom remote connections without modifying PowerShell core engine code. See the above RFC for more details.

A new module repo has been created to serve as an example custom connection, by using the newly public API to create a named pipe custom remote connection. The module is also built in PowerShell CI to allow for testing.

This module will be transferred to the PowerShell repo at some point.
https://github.com/PaulHigin/NamedPipeConnection

## PR Checklist

After executing following command， results are as below picture. It always stays in this state.
` Install-Module ExchangeOnlineManagement`
![PS7](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/78406087/158617230-2c5fc827-b0c1-46a2-a149-55a99bd5760f.PNG)


### Expected behavior

```console
downloaded successfully!
```


### Actual behavior

```console
downloaded 0 out of 100%!
```

_No response_
